docs.lead_paragraph: The next major stop for Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign is the United States Capitol, where the majority leader hopes to burnish his reputation for getting things done with action on different legislative fronts -- from immigration to health insurance. Even before establishing himself as the odds-on choice for the Republican nomination with eight primary victories Tuesday, Mr. Dole made clear that he had no intention of resigning as majority leader to campaign full-time in the country. There are no evident quarrels over his decision. Senator Trent Lott, his deputy, said Tuesday that he would be content to run for the position if Mr. Dole was elected.

headline.main: Dole Hoping To Get Back To Legislating In Congress

docs.lead_paragraph: A House committee today approved legislation that would make it easier for small employers to band together and buy health insurance, but the bill would allow such health plans to avoid all state insurance regulation. The vote, in the Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities, followed party lines. Twenty-four Republicans voted for the bill and 18 Democrats opposed it, saying it would undermine state efforts to adopt more comprehensive health insurance measures.

headline.main: House Panel Approves Bill Easing Rules On Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has gone to the emergency room for a sore throat or cold knows that the bill can be breathtaking. Now a study shows why: hospitals charge double what treatment for nonurgent visits actually costs. Emergency room bills are so exorbitant that insurance companies often try to discourage people from making needless emergency room visits by requiring them to pay a large share of the bill. Some insurers refuse to pay anything if, for example, chest pain turns out to be indigestion rather than a heart attack.

headline.main: In the E.R., Nonemergencies Get a Big Markup

docs.lead_paragraph: After two decades of social pressures that caused many to fear that it might dissolve, the traditional American family is making a comeback in the 1990's, a Washington research group said today in issuing a profile of the country's population. The report, by the Population Reference Bureau Inc., said increases in the number of two-parent households with children, decreases in the divorce rate and other changes suggested that the American family was stabilizing.

headline.main: Traditional Family Stabilized in the 90's, Study Suggests

docs.lead_paragraph: MARIE NATALE'S gynecological problems began 16 years ago. When she was 29, shortly after her son was born, she developed pelvic pain and excessive bleeding caused by advanced endometriosis, extensive growth of uterine tissue outside of the uterus that pressed on other organs and bled monthly into the pelvic cavity. She had surgery to remove the errant tissue and relieve the distress, but two years later, the pain returned. This time the cause was uterine fibroids, benign tumors on the uterine wall. A hysterectomy was recommended, but Ms. Natale hesitated, having heard many reports about unnecessary hysterectomies and their unhappy consequences.

docs.lead_paragraph: Remember high school biology? Most questions were about Mendel's sweet peas, animal family trees and that yucky frog floating in formaldehyde, awaiting dissection. Times have changed. Today, teachers say, biology students are asking different sorts of questions: Is there a gay gene? A fat gene? A mean gene? Is there a genetic reason that so many teen-agers commit suicide? If my mother's younger sister has breast cancer, will I get it, too?

headline.main: Advances in Genetics Give Biology Curriculums a Thought-Provoking New Dimension

docs.lead_paragraph: The Mutual of Omaha Companies said yesterday that it would cut more than 1,000 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, by the end of the year. The company said the job cuts were part of the shift from traditional health insurance to products that offer better opportunities for growth, such as life insurance, annuities and managed health care. About 800 jobs in Omaha and 250 outside Omaha are to be eliminated. The company cited an 8.5 percent decline in health-insurance revenue last year, saying that it had abandoned sales of major-medical and small-group insurance in eight states whose laws the company considered onerous. The states were California, Florida, Kentucky, Maine, New Jersey, New York, Vermont and Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Rises 42.27 Points To Year's 17th Record A renewed optimism in the stock market propelled the Dow Jones industrial average to its 17th record of the year. Surging in the last half-hour of trading, the Dow jumped 42.27 points, to 5,642.42, bringing its three-day gain to 156.80 points, or 2.8 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Union officials said yesterday that 150 clerical workers at Barnard College would return to work today after voting Monday night to suspend their strike. Barnard's clerical workers, library workers and dormitory desk attendants walked out on Feb. 22 after rejecting Barnard's demand that they begin making contributions toward their health insurance premiums.
